AcceptedAnswer:
Let
$$N=(2+\sqrt{5})^p+(2-\sqrt{5})^p.$$
Note that $N$ is an integer. There are various ways to see this. One can for example expand using the binomial theorem, and observe that the terms involving odd powers of $\sqrt{5}$ cancel. Because $(2-\sqrt{5})^p$ is a negative number close to $0$, it follows that
$N=\left\lfloor (2+\sqrt{5})^p\right\rfloor$. In the two binomial expansions, all the binomial coefficients $\binom{p}{k}$ apart from the first and last are divisible by $p$. The first term in each expansion is $2^p$. We conclude that $N\equiv 2\cdot 2^p\pmod{p}$, and the result follows.
